name: Retail guide
desc: A guide aimed towards players playing on official Nintendo hardware or on emulators using only features available on official hardware (ex: no savestate, no access to the internal game state).

name: Emulator guide
desc: A guide aimed towards players playing emulators and having access to emulator-exclusive features such as savestates and access to the internal game state.

name: Seed
desc: Starting value used by the game's random number generator (RNG). Knowing or controlling it allows players to predict and manipulate in-game randomness for desired outcomes.

name: Advance
desc: Process of moving forward in the game's random number sequence. This happens through in-game actions like NPC movement, menu interactions, or specific mechanics that shift the RNG to a new state.

name: Target advance
desc: Specific RNG advance a player aims for a desired outcome. Ex: Advance 1000 for shiny Pokémon.

name: Hit advance
desc: Specific RNG advance a player actually hit when attempting an RNG manipulation. It is usually displayed along the difference with the target advance. Ex: Advance 1007 (+7), where the target advance is 1000.

name: Frame
desc: Single rendered image on the screen, which updates at a consistent rate (~59.7 frames per second on GBA).

name: Calibration (action)
desc: Process of determining the game's timing inconsistencies to accurately predict RNG outcomes.

name: Calibration (value)
desc: Timing variation to counterbalance the game inconsistencies in order to obtain the desired outcome. Ex: +100 ms.

name: Offset
desc: The difference between the RNG advance on the last player input and when the Pokémon generation occurs. Ex: If the offset is 5 and you press A on advance 1000, the Pokémon will be generated on advance 1005.

name: Individual value
desc: Randomly generated number (0-31) assigned to a Pokémon when it is generated. There is one for each stat and it influences the actual stat value.

name: Hexadecimal
desc: Base-16 numbering system where each digit can represent a value from 0 to 15. It uses the digits 0-9 and the letters A-F to represent the values 10-15.

name: Modulo
desc: Mathematic operation to get the remainder when one number is divided by another. For example, 5 mod 3 = 2 because when you divide 5 by 3, the remainder is 2.

name: Trainer ID
desc: Random number generated when starting a new game. It is displayed on their trainer card. It affects whether a Pokémon is shiny.

name: Secret ID
desc: Random number generated when starting a new game. It is never displayed to the player. It affects whether a Pokémon is shiny.

name: Trainer shiny value
desc: Number derived from the Trainer ID and Secret ID. A Pokémon is shiny if its Pokémon shiny value is the same of the original trainer's Trainer shiny value.

name: Personality value
desc: Random number generated for each Pokémon. It determines the gender, ability, nature, and shininess. Personality values are written in hexadecimal format (ex: ABCD1234).

name: Pokémon shiny value
desc: Number derived from the Pokémon Personality value. A Pokémon is shiny if its Pokémon shiny value is the same of the original trainer's Trainer shiny value.

name: Dead battery
desc: No longer functioning game's internal clock. In Ruby & Sapphire, this causes the RNG to start from a fixed seed every time the game boots up. This makes RNG manipulation easier, as players can predict and control Pokémon encounters more consistently.

name: Live battery
desc: Functioning game's internal clock. In Ruby & Sapphire, this causes the RNG to start from a different seed every time the game boots up.

name: Sweet Scent
desc: Attack that can be used outside of battle to trigger a wild Pokémon encounter. Its consistency makes it ideal for RNG manipulation.

name: Synchronize
desc: In Pokémon Emerald, wild Pokémon encounters have 50% chance to share the same Nature as the lead Pokémon if it has the Synchronize ability.

name: Mystic Timer
desc: Timer specifically designed for Pokémon RNG manipulation, available in a browser.

name: Eon Timer
desc: Timer specifically designed for Pokémon RNG manipulation, available as a program.

name: Static Pokémon
desc: Pokémon encounters that predetermined such as starter, stationary, gift, legendary, and roamers Pokémon.

name: Method
desc: A method indicates how a Pokémon will be generated for a given RNG advance.

name: Method-X
desc: Method-1 and Method-4 are the methods for Static Pokémon.

name: Wild-X
desc: Wild-1, Wild-2 and Wild-4 are the methods for wild Pokémon.

name: Lua script
desc: A file with the .lua extension that can be loaded by emulators to help manipulate RNG. Ex: Display the current RNG advance.

name: Reseeding
desc: Resetting the RNG state with a new seed, effectively jumping in the game's random number sequence. Painting and battle video are techniques based on reseeding.

name: Painting technique
desc: Technique to shorthen the wait time to reach high RNG advances by interacting with a painting in the Lilycove Contest Hall. Exclusive to Ruby, Sapphire, and Emerald.

name: Battle video technique
desc: Technique to speed up repeated RNG manipulation attempts by recording a battle video and viewing it to advance the RNG.

name: Noise
desc: Unpredictable factors that cause the RNG to advance in ways that are difficult to control.

name: mGBA
desc: GBA emulator with lua script support which is recommended for RNG manipulation.

name: Effort value
desc: Hidden stat experience given after defeating Pokémon or eating Vitamins. It influences the actual stat value. It is rarely relevant in RNG manipulations.

name: NO$GBA
desc: GBA emulator with a built-in interactive debugger which is useful for RNG manipulation research.

name: Dolphin
desc: GameCube emulator with GBA connectivity.

name: PKHex
desc: Pokémon save editor.

name: Arbitrary code execution
desc: Exploit allowing players to alter the Pokémon generation code. Exclusive to Emerald.

name: VBlank
desc: Mechanism used by the GBA to refresh the screen (~59.7 times per second). VBlank updates the RNG to advance by 1.

name: Cycle counter
desc: Internal counter in the GBA that tracks the number of CPU instructions performed. Every time it reaches 280'896, a VBlank is triggered.

name: Decompiled code
desc: Human-readable code equivalent to the Pokémon game program. It is used to better understand its logic.
